title: 114_s2392
content: The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" limits the removal of Medicare Advantage providers by MA organizations. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" restricts MA organizations from removing providers from MA plans without cause starting in 2017. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" allows MA plans to remove providers if they are medically negligent, violate legal or contractual requirements, or are otherwise unfit to furnish services. Cost to an MA organization offering an MA plan due to a provider's participation in the network cannot be used as a reason to remove the provider mid-year. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" permits MA plans to remove providers for specific reasons, excluding cost considerations. An MA organization can only remove a provider from its network for reasons not specified in the Act 60 days before the annual coordinated election period. Removal can only occur after a notice and appeal process. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" allows MA plans to remove providers from their network for specific reasons, excluding cost considerations. Removal can only happen after a fair notice and appeal process established by the Secretary. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" allows MA plans to remove providers from their network after a fair notice and appeal process, replacing the termination process under section 422.202(a) of title 42, Code of Federal Regulations. The Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015 allows MA plans to remove providers from their network with a 60-day notice to participants receiving services from the provider. The Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015 allows MA plans to remove providers from their network with a 60-day notice to participants. The notification must include names and contact information of in-network providers offering similar services and information on available options for individuals. The Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015 allows MA plans to remove providers from their network with a 60-day notice to participants. The notification must include information on options for continuation of treatment, customer service numbers, and an annual notice of changes. The MA organization offering an MA plan must notify participants of provider removal in the annual notice of change for the upcoming plan year to ensure continuity of care for individuals receiving services from the removed provider. Beginning with plan year 2017, MA organizations offering MA plans must include transparency in measures used to establish or modify provider networks in the annual bid information. This includes information on the quality and efficiency of providers, such as specifications, methodology, and sample size of measures. Enforcement of transparency requirements for MA organizations offering MA plans includes sanctions for noncompliance with the specified information on provider networks. SEC. 3. NETWORK ADEQUACY. Beginning in plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors like anticipated enrollment, services provided, and provider availability when establishing a plan network. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors like anticipated enrollment, services provided, provider availability, and timely provision of care under the plan. This includes assessing the number and types of providers needed, network providers accepting new patients, provider and enrollee locations, and provider availability to ensure services are provided in a timely manner. The Secretary will ensure that providers in Medicare Advantage plans can offer services in a timely manner. Input from various groups will be sought to apply network access standards, and organizations must certify provider network adequacy annually. Medicare Advantage organizations must ensure that providers in their network can offer required services to enrollees. They are required to report average wait times for primary and specialty care, as well as the utilization of out-of-network providers to the Secretary annually. Medicare Advantage organizations must certify the accuracy of provider directories for each plan offered before the annual election period. The Secretary will review the network of each MA plan to ensure compliance. The Secretary ensures that Medicare Advantage plans meet network adequacy guidelines every 3 years or when a material change occurs. Enforcement provisions are amended to include new regulations.
